Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation2: The carpenter should be on time in the work area
Story: I woke up to the sound of my phone buzzing. It was my mom, her voice trembling as she told me Dad hadn’t been sleeping well. I knew I should sit with her, ask if everything was okay, and offer the comfort she needed. That’s what a good son does—makes sure his parents feel supported, especially when things at home seem off. But as I glanced at the clock, my heart pounded. I was already running late for the job site. As a carpenter, I can’t afford to be late; safety briefings start sharp at seven, and missing them means risking not just my own safety, but everyone else’s too. My boss expects me to be there, boots on, ready to follow every protocol. I stood in the hallway, phone in hand, torn between the urge to sit with my mom and the pressure to rush out the door. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding something I couldn’t give at the same time.
